The surgeon is responsible for ensuring that the operation is carried out properly. It is strongly advised that the surgery is performed only by operating surgeons who have acquired the appropriate qualifications, are experienced in spinal surgery, are aware of general risks of spinal surgery, and are familiar with the product-specific surgical procedures. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="4AEFD89F" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00911458" w:rsidRPr="00911458" w:rsidRDefault="00911458" w:rsidP="00911458"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Left"/></w:pPr><w:r w:rsidRPr="00911458"><w:lastRenderedPageBreak/><w:t xml:space="preserve">This device is intended to be used by qualified health care professionals who are experienced in spinal surgery e.g., surgeons, physicians, operating room staff, and individuals involved in preparation of the device. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="647EC859" w14:textId="6E56248D" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="00911458" w:rsidP="00911458"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Left"/></w:pPr><w:r w:rsidRPr="00911458"><w:t>All personnel handling the device should be fully aware that these instructions for use do not include all the information necessary for selection and use of a device. w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="13F813EE" w14:textId="61E3E785" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="00911458" w:rsidP="00DE0969"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>N/A – No Limitations beyond those listed elsewhere in the labeling.</w:t></w:r></w:p></w:tc></w:tr><w:tr w:rsidR="0081776B" w14:paraId="28AAE20A" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidTr="0081776B"><w:tc><w:tcPr><w:tcW w:w="4077" w:type="dxa"/><w:tcBorders><w:top w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders><w:shd w:val="clear" w:color="auto" w:fill="BFBFBF" w:themeFill="background1" w:themeFillShade="BF"/></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="295BC880" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="0081776B" w:rsidP="0081776B"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableHeader10-Left"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>Adverse Events/Side-Effects:</w:t></w:r></w:p></w:tc><w:tc><w:tcPr><w:tcW w:w="5183" w:type="dxa"/><w:tcBorders><w:top w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="4127A327" w14:textId="3E55A3E8" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00DE0969"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r w:rsidRPr="00466746"><w:t>As with all major surgical procedures, there is a risk of adverse events. Possible adverse events may include: problems resulting from anesthesia and patient positioning; thrombosis; embolism; infection; excessive bleeding; neural and vascular injury; swelling, abnormal wound healing or scar formation; heterotopic ossification; functional impairment of the musculoskeletal system; paralysis (temporary or permanent); complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS); allergy/hypersensitivity reactions; symptoms associated with implant or hardware prominence; dysphagia; malunion; non-union; ongoing pain; damage to adjacent bones, discs, organs, or other soft tissues; dural tear or spinal fluid leak; spinal cord compression and/or contusion; esophageal perforation; erosion or irritation; device or graft displacement; dislocation of graft material; vertebral angulation.</w:t></w:r></w:p></w:tc></w:tr><w:tr w:rsidR="0081776B" w14:paraId="197A35C9" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidTr="0081776B"><w:tc><w:tcPr><w:tcW w:w="4077" w:type="dxa"/><w:tcBorders><w:top w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders><w:shd w:val="clear" w:color="auto" w:fill="BFBFBF" w:themeFill="background1" w:themeFillShade="BF"/></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="3EAE6F6D" w14:textId="0FEA465C" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="0081776B" w:rsidP="0081776B"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableHeader10-Left"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>Warnings</w:t></w:r><w:r w:rsidR="00466746"><w:t xml:space="preserve"> and Precautions</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t>:</w:t></w:r></w:p></w:tc><w:tc><w:tcPr><w:tcW w:w="5183" w:type="dxa"/><w:tcBorders><w:top w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="459F3E1B" w14:textId="75B7030E" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t xml:space="preserve">It is strongly advised that ZERO-P is implanted only by operating surgeons who have acquired the appropriate qualifications, are experienced in spinal surgery, are aware of general risks of spinal surgery, and are familiar with the product-specific surgical procedures. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="091E60B6" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Implantation is to take place with the in¬structions for the recommended surgical procedure. The surgeon is responsible for ensuring that the operation is carried out properly.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="6D70E3DB" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t xml:space="preserve">The manufacturer is not responsible for any complications arising from incorrect diagnosis, choice of </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:lastRenderedPageBreak/><w:t>incorrect implant, incorrectly combined implant components and/or operating techniques, the limitations of treatment methods, or inadequate asepsis.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="1EE23C2D" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Patient positioning and exposure</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="682B4850" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Position the patient in a supine position on a radiolucent operating table. Careful positioning of the retractor is required to protect against soft tissue damage.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="5F820738" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Trial insertion</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="1A5BC73D" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>After the discectomy is complete, choose a parallel lordotic or convex trial spacer of the appropriate height and depth. The trial spacers do not have a depth limiter, an image intensifier should be used to check the position during insertion. With the segment fully distracted, the trial spacer should fit tightly between the end plates. Choose the appropriate implant footprint and size to accommodate variation in patient anatomy; failure to do so may injure the patient.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="4DF7251C" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>To minimize potential risk to the patient, it is recommended to use shorter height trial spacers before using taller trial spacers, and to use standard size footprint trial spacers before using large footprint size trial spacers.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="1D57749F" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Implant Insertion</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="3F21BC3F" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t xml:space="preserve">Placement of ZERO-P adjacent to a previous, multi-level fusion could result in increased loading on the screws. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="0C3F977A" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Additional posterior supplemental fixation should be considered in cases where ZERO-P is placed adjacent to a previous, multi-level fusion.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="7EA2EDF2" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Do not orient ZERO-P implants having convex sagittal profiles with medial screws facing cranial.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="4B8F59D2" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Orienting convex sagittal profile implants with medial screws facing cranial may prevent proper seating of the implant between vertebral bodies.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="55759F56" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Use the aiming device and the implant holder to introduce the implant into the disc space. The aiming device and implant holder do not have a depth limiter; therefore, an image intensifier should be used to check the position while inserting.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="1C6E7C1D" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Once the implant is inserted, verify final implant position relative to vertebral bodies in the anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views and remaining implanted hardware associated with previously fused level using intraoperative imaging. The PEEK cage has a single posterior radiopaque market incorporated into the implant to enable intraoperative radiographic assessment of the implant position.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="559C1E27" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:lastRenderedPageBreak/><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Confirm that the ZERO-P implant is not placed in direct contact with implanted hardware associated with the previously fused level.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="613DB228" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>If the ZERO-P implant remains in direct contact with hardware associated with the previously fused level, increased loading may be placed on the ZERO-P implant leading to potential post-operative device failure and potential harm to the patient.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="16E88944" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Screw Fixation</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="71E6BC48" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Before drilling a hole, intraoperative imaging should be used to verify drill position.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="3BD21A68" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t xml:space="preserve">If adjacent hardware all four screws from being implanted, a different device should be used, as increased loading may be placed on the screws leading to potential post-operative device failure and potentially increased harm to the patient. </w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="064BD230" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>If any screw cannot be inserted at the correct trajectory or locked to the plate, a different device should be used to avoid the potential risk of screw backout or screw failure.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="25CB3D14" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>When awl is used instead of drill, intraoperative imaging should be used to verify awl position.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="00F2E03E" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Take care that the awl does not move the implant relative to the vertebral body. For particularly hard bone, drilling is recommended to minimize implant movement.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="009151F1" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>When using the drill bit in combination with the aiming device, take care to apply only axial forces to the drill bit. Bending forces applied when the tip of the drill bit is engaged in the aiming device can lead to the drill bit breaking.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="62012C7E" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>While using the screwdriver, if the torque limiter is not used, breakage of the screwdriver may occur and could potentially harm the patient.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="6214CDF9" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>During screw insertion, intraoperative imaging should be used to verify screw position.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="532EC623" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>The screws should be tightened only after all screws have been inserted.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="44741025" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Implant removal</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="339C36B5" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Screw loosening with the torque limiting handle may damage the torque limiting handle. Therefore, always use the standard handle for screw loosening.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="0AEB7A60" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>While removing screw using conical extraction screw, drilling into the screw recess with the 2.0 mm drill bit will cause metal debris. Use of suction and irrigation is recommended to remove the debris from the wound.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="06C26655" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Do not use the conical extraction screw with power tools.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="6ADC79DB" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:lastRenderedPageBreak/><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Use of power tools with conical extraction screw may potentially damage the screw recess and/ or extraction screw, preventing subsequent removal.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="273BC27E" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Boxlevel2"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>o</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>Do not use the conical extraction screw with the torque limiting attachment, as this prohibits removal of the screws and may cause additional damage to the instrumentation.</w:t></w:r></w:p><w:p w14:paraId="44F5819D" w14:textId="3AA12009" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00466746"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableCell10-Box"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:t>•</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:tab/><w:t>For more information, please refer to the Synthes brochure “Important Information”.</w:t></w:r></w:p></w:tc></w:tr><w:tr w:rsidR="0081776B" w14:paraId="79FFF919" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidTr="0081776B"><w:tc><w:tcPr><w:tcW w:w="4077" w:type="dxa"/><w:tcBorders><w:top w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders><w:shd w:val="clear" w:color="auto" w:fill="BFBFBF" w:themeFill="background1" w:themeFillShade="BF"/></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="2F2102EB" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="0081776B" w:rsidRDefault="0081776B" w:rsidP="0081776B"><w:pPr><w:pStyle w:val="TableHeader10-Left"/></w:pPr><w:r><w:lastRenderedPageBreak/><w:t>Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Compatibility:</w:t></w:r></w:p></w:tc><w:tc><w:tcPr><w:tcW w:w="5183" w:type="dxa"/><w:tcBorders><w:top w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:left w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:bottom w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/><w:right w:val="single" w:sz="4" w:space="0" w:color="auto"/></w:tcBorders></w:tcPr><w:p w14:paraId="58EB22DF" demonstrated that the implants of the </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve">ZERO-P system </w:t></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="00657067"><w:t xml:space="preserve">are MR conditional. w:val="FootnoteReference"/></w:rPr><w:footnoteReference w:id="3"/></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:t xml:space="preserve"> of the device is considered complete when the fusion mass has developed sufficient strength to maintain the stability and conformation of the spinal segment without external support. The difficulty in determining the appropriate duration of therapeutic lifetime stems from the variability in time to fusion based on important mechanical, vascular, cellular, and molecular influences</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Kalfas</Author><Year>2001</Year><RecNum>31</RecNum><DisplayText>(Kalfas, 2001)</DisplayText><record><rec-number>31</rec-number><foreign-keys><key app="EN" db-id="wwfwvrw5azfrxgefsx4vtd9ixzr2ffvxatsf" timestamp="1600240117">31</key></foreign-keys><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Iain H. Kalfas</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>Principles of bone healing</title><secondary-title>Neurosurgical Focus FOC</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Neurosurgical Focus FOC</full-title></periodical><pages>1-4</pages><volume>10</volume><number>4</number><dates><year>2001</year></dates><publisher>American Association of Neurological Surgeons</publisher><urls><related-urls><url>https://thejns.org/focus/view/journals/neurosurg-focus/10/4/foc.2001.10.4.2.xml</url></related-urls></urls><electronic-resource-num>10.3171/foc.2001.10.4.2</electronic-resource-num><language>English</language></record></Cite></EndNote></w:instrText></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="separate"/></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/><w:noProof/></w:rPr><w:t>(</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink w:anchor="_ENREF_42" w:tooltip="Kalfas, 2001 #31" w:history="1"><w:r w:rsidR="00082D4B"><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/><w:noProof/></w:rPr><w:t>Kalfas, 2001</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/><w:noProof/></w:rPr><w:t>)</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="end"/></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:t>. At this time, it is impossible to predict the exact duration required to heal a fusion</w:t></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:rPr><w:vertAlign w:val="superscript"/></w:rPr><w:footnoteReference w:id="4"/></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:t xml:space="preserve">, however, based on human and animal data it is generally accepted that a fusion will have healed post-operatively within </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t>six</w:t></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:t xml:space="preserve"> months</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"><w:fldData xml:space="preserve">PEVuZE5vdGU+PENpdGU+PEF1dGhvcj5MYXJzZW48L0F1dGhvcj48WWVhcj4xOTk3PC9ZZWFyPjxS

The process of bone graft incorporation in a spinal fusion model is similar to the bone healing process that occurs in fractured long bones </w:t></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/></w:r><w:r><w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Boden</Author><Year>1995</Year><RecNum>1223</RecNum><DisplayText>(Boden et al., 1995)</DisplayText><record><rec-number>1223</rec-number><foreign-keys><key app="EN" db-id="95fzxrr0jdw99te90aup50pmtwzd2t9vvs9x" timestamp="1592584360">1223</key></foreign-keys><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Boden, S. D.</author><author>Schimandle, J. H.</author><author>Hutton, W. C.</author></authors></contributors><auth-address>Emory Spine Center, Department of Orthopaedics, Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, Georgia, USA.</auth-address><titles><title>An experimental lumbar intertransverse process spinal fusion model. Radiographic, histologic, and biomechanical healing characteristics</title><secondary-title>Spine (Phila Pa 1976)</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Spine (Phila Pa 1976)</full-title></periodical><pages>412-20</pages><volume>20</volume><number>4</number><edition>1995/02/15</edition><keywords><keyword>Animals</keyword><keyword>Biomechanical Phenomena</keyword><keyword>Lumbosacral Region</keyword><keyword>Rabbits</keyword><keyword>Radiography</keyword><keyword>Spinal Fusion/*methods</keyword><keyword>Spine/*diagnostic imaging/*pathology/physiopathology</keyword><keyword>*Wound Healing</keyword></keywords><dates><year>1995</year><pub-dates><date>Feb 15</date></pub-dates></dates><isbn>0362-2436 (Print)&#xD;0362-2436 (Linking)</isbn><accession-num>7747224</accession-num><urls><related-urls><url>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7747224</url></related-urls></urls><electronic-resource-num>10.1097/00007632-199502001-00003</electronic-resource-num></record></Cite></EndNote></w:instrText></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="separate"/></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:rPr><w:noProof/></w:rPr><w:t>(</w:t></w:r><w:hyperlink w:anchor="_ENREF_9" w:tooltip="Boden, 1995 #1223" w:history="1"><w:r w:rsidR="00082D4B" w:rsidRPr="001C50CA"><w:rPr><w:noProof/></w:rPr><w:t>Boden et al., 1995</w:t></w:r></w:hyperlink><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:rPr><w:noProof/></w:rPr><w:t>)</w:t></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="end"/></w:r><w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD"><w:t>. Fracture healing occurs in three distinct but overlapping stages: 1) the early inflammatory stage; 2) the repair stage; and 3) the late remodeling stage. Healing is completed during the remodeling stage in which the healing bone is restored to its original shape, structure, and mechanical strength. Remodeling of the bone occurs slowly over months to years and is facilitated by mechanical stress placed on the bone. As the fracture site is exposed to an axial loading force, bone is generally laid down where it is needed and resorbed from where it is not needed. Adequate strength is typically achieved in 3 to 6 months</w:t></w:r><w:r><w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/></w:r><w:r><w:rPr><w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/></w:rPr><w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Kalfas</Author><Year>2001</Year><RecNum>31</RecNum><DisplayText>(Kalfas, 2001)</DisplayText><record><rec-number>31</rec-number><foreign-keys><key app="EN" db-id="wwfwvrw5azfrxgefsx4vtd9ixzr2ffvxatsf" timestamp="1600240117">31</key></foreign-keys><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Iain H.                 <w:p w14:paraId="527898F9" w14:textId="15DBA877" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B" w:rsidP="007770FD">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level0"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r>
                    <w:t xml:space="preserve">If the device contains or incorporates: </w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
                <w:p w14:paraId="683BB5FE" w14:textId="27D03778" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRPr="00D03710" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level1"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00D03710">
                    <w:t>a medicinal substance, including human blood or plasma derivative</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
                <w:p w14:paraId="55C1BA2C" w14:textId="4DB61D46" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRPr="00D03710" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level1"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00D03710">
                    <w:t>tissue(s) or cells, or their derivatives, of human origin</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
                <w:p w14:paraId="28F9FD8A" w14:textId="7B0E4889" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRPr="00D03710" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level1"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00D03710">
                    <w:t>tissue(s) or cells, or their derivatives, of animal origin (per EU Reg No. 722/2012)</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
                <w:p w14:paraId="04100F37" w14:textId="0BDE2043" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRPr="00D03710" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level1"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00D03710">
                    <w:t>a substance that is absorbed or dispersed in body (for devices intended to be introduced via a body orifice or applied to the skin)</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
                <w:p w14:paraId="772473AA" w14:textId="1D437F0F" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRPr="00D03710" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level1"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00D03710">
                    <w:t>a restricted substance (</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r>
                    <w:t xml:space="preserve">i.e., </w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00092B75">
                    <w:t>CMR</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r>
                    <w:t xml:space="preserve"> [</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00092B75">
                    <w:t>carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic to reproduction</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r>
                    <w:t>]</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00092B75">
                    <w:t xml:space="preserve"> substances or</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r>
                    <w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00092B75">
                    <w:t>endocrine-disrupting substances</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r>
                    <w:t>)</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
                <w:p w14:paraId="12A0D18D" w14:textId="4C7633EC" w:rsidR="00831B3B" w:rsidRPr="00623350" w:rsidRDefault="00831B3B">
                  <w:pPr>
                    <w:pStyle w:val="TableBullet11-Level1"/>
                  </w:pPr>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="00D03710">
                    <w:t>materials that could result in sensitization</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                  <w:r w:rsidRPr="001C2FBE">
                    <w:t xml:space="preserve"> or allergic reaction</w:t>
                  </w:r>
                </w:p>
              </w:tc>
              <w:tc>

          <w:p w14:paraId="1C465667" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00396B5C" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00481751">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>The ZERO-P system is a stand-alone device for use in cervical interbody fusion, designed to combine the functionality of a cervical interbody cage with an anterior cervical plate with four cervical locking screws.</w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
          <w:p w14:paraId="299D8D2C" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00466746" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00481751">

            </w:pPr>
          </w:p>

                <w:iCs/>

              <w:t>Device(s) do(es) not contain any medicinal substances, tissues or cells of human or animal origin, any materials incorporated into the device that contain or consist of carcinogenic, mutagenic or toxic to reproduction (CMR), or materials that could result in sensitization or allergic reaction (beyond those materials listed above).</w:t>

      <w:tr w:rsidR="00396B5C" w14:paraId="5C24BA7A" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidTr="001C3EEF">
        <w:tc>
          <w:tcPr>
            <w:tcW w:w="2533" w:type="dxa"/>
            <w:shd w:val="clear" w:color="auto" w:fill="BFBFBF" w:themeFill="background1" w:themeFillShade="BF"/>
          </w:tcPr>
          <w:p w14:paraId="20215BD5" w14:textId="34D755DD" w:rsidR="00396B5C" w:rsidRDefault="00396B5C" w:rsidP="00396B5C">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableHeader11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>Principles of Operation</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidR="007D26DA">
              <w:t>:</w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
        </w:tc>
        <w:tc>
          <w:tcPr>
            <w:tcW w:w="6727" w:type="dxa"/>
          </w:tcPr>
          <w:p w14:paraId="3ACCC169" w14:textId="04D7A7BA" w:rsidR="00396B5C" w:rsidRDefault="00466746" w:rsidP="00481751">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="001B22D5">
              <w:t>The ZERO-P implant</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>s</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="001B22D5">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>are</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="001B22D5">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> stand-alone device</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>s</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="001B22D5">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> for use in cervical interbody fusion, designed to combine the functionality of a cervical interbody cage with an anterior cervical plate. </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">The cages are designed to provide stabilization of the motion segment(s) </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00B450C2">
              <w:t>following anterior cervical discectomy</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>, as an adjunct to anterior</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00B450C2">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> cervical interbody fusion. </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00161A2C">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">The exact technique </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">regarding preparation for the </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00161A2C">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">subject devices is dictated by surgeon preference. </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">The devices are applied via an open, anterior exposure of the cervical spine. </w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
        </w:tc>
      </w:tr>
      <w:tr w:rsidR="00396B5C" w14:paraId="6E3CEECC" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidTr="001C3EEF">
        <w:tc>
          <w:tcPr>
            <w:tcW w:w="2533" w:type="dxa"/>
            <w:shd w:val="clear" w:color="auto" w:fill="BFBFBF" w:themeFill="background1" w:themeFillShade="BF"/>
          </w:tcPr>
          <w:p w14:paraId="0812B24A" w14:textId="73737713" w:rsidR="00396B5C" w:rsidRDefault="00396B5C" w:rsidP="00396B5C">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableHeader11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>Mode of Action:</w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
        </w:tc>
        <w:tc>
          <w:tcPr>
            <w:tcW w:w="6727" w:type="dxa"/>
          </w:tcPr>
          <w:p w14:paraId="504E7DCD" w14:textId="18BFE09D" w:rsidR="00396B5C" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00481751">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>The mode of action for the implants is mechanical; once the cage is inserted into the disc space, the screws are anchored into the adjacent vertebral bodies.</w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
        </w:tc>
      </w:tr>

          <w:p w14:paraId="7576E272" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00C72E81" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00C72E81">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="Header"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:lastRenderedPageBreak/>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">Therapeutic (Functional) Lifetime </w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
          <w:p w14:paraId="6CDA2E6A" w14:textId="61A4C610" w:rsidR="00C72E81" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00C72E81">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">The ZERO-P Stand-Alone Implants are utilized to stabilize the motion segment(s) after the removal of an intervertebral body disc while bony fusion occurs. </w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
          <w:p w14:paraId="09339438" w14:textId="1292DD25" w:rsidR="00C72E81" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00C72E81">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t>The therapeutic lifetime</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:rStyle w:val="FootnoteReference"/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:footnoteReference w:id="3"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> of the device is considered complete when the fusion mass has developed sufficient strength to maintain the stability and conformation of the spinal segment without external support. The difficulty in determining the appropriate duration of therapeutic lifetime stems from the variability in time to fusion based on important mechanical, vascular, cellular, and molecular influences</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:rFonts w:eastAsia="Times New Roman"/>

            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t>. At this time, it is impossible to predict the exact duration required to heal a fusion</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:rPr>
                <w:vertAlign w:val="superscript"/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:footnoteReference w:id="4"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">, however, based on human and animal data it is generally accepted that a fusion will have healed post-operatively within </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>six</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> months</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t>
            </w:r>

            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">. The process of bone graft incorporation in a spinal fusion model is similar to the bone healing process that occurs in fractured long bones </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/>

            <w:r w:rsidRPr="006E4BDD">
              <w:t>. Fracture healing occurs in three distinct but overlapping stages: 1) the early inflammatory stage; 2) the repair stage; and 3) the late remodeling stage. Healing is completed during the remodeling stage in which the healing bone is restored to its original shape, structure, and mechanical strength. Remodeling of the bone occurs slowly over months to years and is facilitated by mechanical stress placed on the bone. As the fracture site is exposed to an axial loading force, bone is generally laid down where it is needed and resorbed from where it is not needed. Adequate strength is typically achieved in 3 to 6 months</w:t>
            </w:r>

              <w:t xml:space="preserve">A conservative estimate of therapeutic lifetime is assumed based on these facts to be 12-18 months to account for variability in time to fusion as well as the potential for delayed diagnosis of non-union </w:t>

          <w:p w14:paraId="1AC9D7A0" w14:textId="344B3AF8" w:rsidR="00C72E81" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00C72E81">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">The subject devices were tested in dynamic compression (Section </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> REF _Ref37344999 \r \h  \* MERGEFORMAT </w:instrText>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="separate"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>6.2</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="end"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">) per ASTM F2077-03 to verify the integrity of the devices over the functional lifetime. All devices tested successfully completed the full 5,000,000 cycle test (which equates to approximately 2.5 years of human activity) at 3,000 N or more </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Hedman</Author><Year>1991</Year><RecNum>1117</RecNum><DisplayText>(Hedman et al., 1991)</DisplayText><record><rec-number>1117</rec-number><foreign-keys><key app="EN" db-id="95fzxrr0jdw99te90aup50pmtwzd2t9vvs9x" timestamp="1589999385">1117</key></foreign-keys><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Hedman, T. P.</author><author>Kostuik, J. P.</author><author>Fernie, G. R.</author><author>Hellier, W. G.</author></authors></contributors><auth-address>Orthopaedic Biomechanics Laboratory, Toronto General Hospital, Ontario, Canada.</auth-address><titles><title>Design of an intervertebral disc prosthesis</title><secondary-title>Spine (Phila Pa 1976)</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Spine (Phila Pa 1976)</full-title></periodical><pages>S256-60</pages><volume>16</volume><number>6 Suppl</number><edition>1991/06/01</edition><keywords><keyword>Chromium Alloys</keyword><keyword>Humans</keyword><keyword>*Intervertebral Disc</keyword><keyword>*Lumbar Vertebrae</keyword><keyword>Molybdenum</keyword><keyword>*Prostheses and Implants</keyword><keyword>Prosthesis Design</keyword></keywords><dates><year>1991</year><pub-dates><date>Jun</date></pub-dates></dates><isbn>0362-2436 (Print)&#xD;0362-2436 (Linking)</isbn><accession-num>1862421</accession-num><urls><related-urls><url>https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1862421</url></related-urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote></w:instrText>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="separate"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:noProof/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:t>(</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:hyperlink w:anchor="_ENREF_36" w:tooltip="Hedman, 1991 #1117" w:history="1">
              <w:r w:rsidR="00082D4B" w:rsidRPr="001C50CA">
                <w:rPr>
                  <w:noProof/>
                </w:rPr>
                <w:t>Hedman et al., 1991</w:t>
              </w:r>
            </w:hyperlink>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:noProof/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:t>)</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="end"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">. These loads are comparable to maximum daily body loads (3,400 N or less) experienced in the spine. 5,000,000 cycles at these loads represents a greater challenge than the device is likely to experience in vivo, based on the vertebral endplate failure strength with a single central device (2,037 N ± 1193 N) and expected daily loads (300 N to 1850 N) </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="begin"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:instrText xml:space="preserve"> ADDIN EN.CITE <EndNote><Cite><Author>Labrom</Author><Year>2005</Year><RecNum>1414</RecNum><DisplayText>(Labrom et al., 2005)</DisplayText><record><rec-number>1414</rec-number><foreign-keys><key app="EN" db-id="95fzxrr0jdw99te90aup50pmtwzd2t9vvs9x" timestamp="1596036875">1414</key></foreign-keys><ref-type name="Journal Article">17</ref-type><contributors><authors><author>Labrom, Robert D</author><author>Tan, Juay-Seng</author><author>Reilly, Christopher W</author><author>Tredwell, Stephen J</author><author>Fisher, Charles G</author><author>Oxland, Thomas R</author></authors></contributors><titles><title>The effect of interbody cage positioning on lumbosacral vertebral endplate failure in compression</title><secondary-title>Spine</secondary-title></titles><periodical><full-title>Spine</full-title></periodical><pages>E556-E561</pages><volume>30</volume><number>19</number><dates><year>2005</year></dates><isbn>0362-2436</isbn><urls></urls></record></Cite></EndNote></w:instrText>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:fldChar w:fldCharType="separate"/>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:noProof/>
              </w:rPr>
              <w:t>(</w:t>
            </w:r>

          <w:p w14:paraId="4C61E034" w14:textId="77777777" w:rsidR="00C72E81" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00C72E81">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="Header"/>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>Post-Therapeutic (Actual) Lifetime</w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
          <w:p w14:paraId="58B39ED9" w14:textId="23642329" w:rsidR="00CE3A1B" w:rsidRPr="009D11DE" w:rsidRDefault="00C72E81" w:rsidP="00C72E81">
            <w:pPr>
              <w:pStyle w:val="TableCell11-Left"/>
              <w:rPr>
                <w:rFonts w:eastAsia="MS Gothic"/>
              </w:rPr>
            </w:pPr>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00C72E81">
              <w:t>The ZERO-P implants are intended for permanent implantation (>30days) as per the system indications listed in the Instructions for Use</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="001E3989">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r>
              <w:t>(</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00C72E81">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve">SE_481667, SE_489867). The post-therapeutic lifetime of the device can be considered the remaining lifetime of the patient, as ZERO-P </w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidR="005F416B">
              <w:t>is</w:t>
            </w:r>
            <w:r w:rsidRPr="00C72E81">
              <w:t xml:space="preserve"> not typically removed.</w:t>
            </w:r>
          </w:p>
        </w:tc>
      </w:tr>
